statement.p:
Consider the system of linear equations
\begin{alignedat}{4} x \amp {}+{} \amp 2y \amp {}-{} \amp z \amp {}={} \amp 1 \\ 3x \amp {}+{} \amp 2y \amp {}+{} \amp 2z \amp {}={} \amp 7 \\ -x \amp \amp \amp {}+{} \amp 4z \amp {}={} \amp -3 \\ \end{alignedat} .
Find the matrix A and vector \bvec that expresses this linear system in the form A\xvec=\bvec.
Give a description of the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \bvec.

li.p:
We have
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ 3 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 7 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 4 \amp -3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]
so there is a unique solution \xvec=\threevec{3}{-1}{0}.

statement.p: Suppose that A is a 135\times2201 matrix, and that \xvec is a vector. If A\xvec is defined, what is the dimension of \xvec? What is the dimension of A\xvec?

solution.p: If A\xvec is defined, then \xvec\in\real^{2201} and A\xvec\in\real^{135}.

statement.p:
Suppose that A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ -1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] .
Describe the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \zerovec.
Find a 3\times2 matrix B with no zero entries such that AB = 0.

li.p:
We form B by choosing two vectors in the solution space to A\xvec=\zerovec. For instance,
B = \left[\begin{array}{rr} -2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}

statement.p:
Consider the matrix
A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -4 \amp -4 \\ 2 \amp 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 4 \amp 6 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Find the product A\xvec where
\xvec = \fourvec{1}{-2}{0}{2} .
Give a description of the vectors \xvec such that
A\xvec = \threevec{-1}{15}{17} .
Find the reduced row echelon form of A and identify the pivot positions.
Can you find a vector \bvec such that A\xvec=\bvec is inconsistent?
For a general 3-dimensional vector \bvec, what can you say about the solution space of the equation A\xvec = \bvec?

li.p:
We consider the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp -4 \amp -4 \amp -1 \\ 2 \amp 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 15 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 4 \amp 6 \amp 17 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 9 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right]
so that \xvec=\fourvec{9-2x_4}{-1+x_4}{2-x_4}{x_4} =\fourvec{9}{-1}{2}{0}+x_4\fourvec{-2}{1}{-1}{1}.

There is no vector \bvec such that A\xvec=\bvec is inconsistent because the augmented matrix \left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right] cannot have a pivot position in the rightmost column.

The coefficient matrix \left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right] will have exactly one column without a pivot position. Therefore, the solution space will form a line in \real^4, as in part b.
The solution space will form a line in \real^4, as in part b.

statement.p: The operations that we perform in Gaussian elimination can be accomplished using matrix multiplication. This observation is the basis of an important technique that we will investigate in a subsequent chapter.

Let's consider the matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ -3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Suppose that S = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 7 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] . Verify that SA is the matrix that results when the second row of A is scaled by a factor of 7. What matrix S would scale the third row by -3?
Suppose that P = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] . Verify that PA is the matrix that results from interchanging the first and second rows. What matrix P would interchange the first and third rows?
Suppose that L_1 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] . Verify that L_1A is the matrix that results from multiplying the first row of A by -2 and adding it to the second row. What matrix L_2 would multiply the first row by 3 and add it to the third row?
When we performed Gaussian elimination, our first goal was to perform row operations that brought the matrix into a triangular form. For our matrix A, find the row operations needed to find a row equivalent matrix U in triangular form. By expressing these row operations in terms of matrix multiplication, find a matrix L such that LA = U.

li.p:
We compute that L_1A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ -3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp -4 \amp 4 \\ -3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}
To multiply the first row by 3 and add to the third row, we would use L_2= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
To scale the third row by -3, we would use the matrix S= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] .
To interchange the first and third rows, we would use P= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
To multiply the first row by 3 and add to the third row, we would use L_2= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
In this exercise, you will construct the inverse of a matrix, a subject that we will investigate more fully in the next chapter. Suppose that A is the 2\times2 matrix:
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Find the vectors \bvec_1 and \bvec_2 such that the matrix B=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \bvec_1 \amp \bvec_2 \end{array}\right] satisfies
AB = I = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
In general, it is not true that AB = BA. Check that it is true, however, for the specific A and B that appear in this problem.
Suppose that \xvec = \twovec{x_1}{x_2}. What do you find when you evaluate I\xvec?
Suppose that we want to solve the equation A\xvec = \bvec. We know how to do this using Gaussian elimination; let's use our matrix B to find a different way:
\begin{aligned} A\xvec \amp {}={} \bvec \\ B(A\xvec) \amp {}={} B\bvec \\ (BA)\xvec \amp {}={} B\bvec \\ I\xvec \amp {}={} B\bvec \\ \xvec \amp {}={} B\bvec \\ \end{aligned} . In other words, the solution to the equation A\xvec=\bvec is \xvec = B\bvec.
Consider the equation A\xvec = \twovec{5}{-2}. Find the solution in two different ways, first using Gaussian elimination and then as \xvec = B\bvec, and verify that you have found the same result.

li.p: It is true, in this case, that AB=BA=I.
If \bvec=\twovec{5}{-2}, then \xvec=B\bvec=\twovec{-1}{-4} is the solution to the equation A\xvec=\bvec.
It is true, in this case, that AB=BA=I.

statement.p:
Determine whether the following statements are true or false and provide a justification for your response.
If A\xvec is defined, then the number of components of \xvec equals the number of rows of A.
The solution space to the equation A\xvec = \bvec is equivalent to the solution space to the linear system whose augmented matrix is \left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right].
If a linear system of equations has 8 equations and 5 unknowns, then the shape of the matrix A in the corresponding equation A\xvec = \bvec is 5\times8.
If A has a pivot position in every row, then every equation A\xvec = \bvec is consistent.
If A is a 9\times5 matrix, then A\xvec=\bvec is inconsistent for some vector \bvec.

li.p: False, the number of components of \xvec equals the number of columns of A.
True. This is a result of .
False. The shape of A is 8\times5.

True, because the augmented matrix \left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]
cannot have a pivot position in the rightmost column.

True. Because there is not a pivot position in every row of A, the augmented matrix \left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]
will have a pivot position in the rightmost column for some vectors \bvec.

statement.p:
Suppose that A is a 4\times4 matrix and that the equation A\xvec = \bvec has a unique solution for some vector \bvec.
What does this say about the pivot positions of the matrix A? Write the reduced row echelon form of A.
Can you find another vector \cvec such that A\xvec = \cvec is inconsistent?
What can you say about the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \zerovec?
Suppose A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \amp \vvec_4 \end{array}\right]. Explain why every four-dimensional vector can be written as a linear combination of the vectors \vvec_1, \vvec_2, \vvec_3, and \vvec_4 in exactly one way.

li.p: Since the solution is unique, there must be a pivot position in every column of A. This means that there are four pivot positions so there is a pivot position in every row. In other words, A \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
No, because A has a pivot in every row.
There is only one solution, which is \xvec=\zerovec.

If \bvec is a four-dimensional vector, then A\xvec=\bvec has a unique solution since A has a pivot position in every row and every column. This means that \bvec can be written as a linear combination of the columns of A in exactly one way.
Every equation A\xvec=\bvec has exactly one solution.

statement.p:
Define the matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -3 \\ 3 \amp 1 \amp 7 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Describe the solution space to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec using a parametric description, if appropriate. What does this solution space represent geometrically?
Describe the solution space to the equation A\xvec=\bvec where \bvec = \threevec{-3}{-4}{1}. What does this solution space represent geometrically and how does it compare to the previous solution space?
We will now explain the relationship between the previous two solution spaces. Suppose that \xvec_h is a solution to the homogeneous equation; that is A\xvec_h=\zerovec. Suppose also that \xvec_p is a solution to the equation A\xvec = \bvec; that is, A\xvec_p=\bvec.
Use the Linearity Principle expressed in to explain why \xvec_h+\xvec_p is a solution to the equation A\xvec = \bvec. You may do this by evaluating A(\xvec_h+\xvec_p).
That is, if we find one solution \xvec_p to an equation A\xvec = \bvec, we may add any solution to the homogeneous equation to \xvec_p and still have a solution to the equation A\xvec = \bvec. In other words, the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \bvec is given by translating the solution space to the homogeneous equation by the vector \xvec_p.

li.p:
We have the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 1 \amp 7 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]
so that \xvec = x_3\threevec{-2}{-1}{1}. The solution space is a line that passes through the origin.

Now we have
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \amp -3 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp -4 \\ 3 \amp 1 \amp 7 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]
so that \xvec=\threevec{1}{-2}{0}+x_3\threevec{-2}{-1}{1}. This is a line through \threevec{1}{-2}{0} parallel to \threevec{-2}{-1}{1}. Notice that this line is parallel to the line in part a.

Notice that A(\xvec_h + \xvec_p) = A\xvec_h + A\xvec_p = \zerovec + \bvec = \bvec. This shows that if we add a vector from the solution space to A\xvec=\zerovec to a vector from the solution space to A\xvec=\bvec, we obtain a vector in the solution space to A\xvec=\bvec.

statement.p: Suppose that a city is starting a bicycle sharing program with bicycles at locations B and C. Bicycles that are rented at one location may be returned to either location at the end of the day. Over time, the city finds that 80% of bicycles rented at location B are returned to B with the other 20% returned to C. Similarly, 50% of bicycles rented at location C are returned to B and 50% to C.

To keep track of the bicycles, we form a vector
\xvec_k = \twovec{B_k}{C_k}
where B_k is the number of bicycles at location B at the beginning of day k and C_k is the number of bicycles at C. The information above tells us how to determine the distribution of bicycles the following day:
\begin{alignedat}{3} B_{k+1} \amp {}={} 0.8B_k \amp {}+{} \amp 0.5 C_k \\ C_{k+1} \amp {}={} 0.2B_k \amp {}+{} \amp 0.5 C_k. \\ \end{alignedat}
Expressed in matrix-vector form, these expressions give
\xvec_{k+1} = A\xvec_k
where
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.8 \amp 0.5 \\ 0.2 \amp 0.5 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Let's check that this makes sense.
Suppose that there are 1000 bicycles at location B and none at C on day 1. This means we have \xvec_1 = \twovec{1000}{0}. Find the number of bicycles at both locations on day 2 by evaluating \xvec_2 = A\xvec_1.
Suppose that there are 1000 bicycles at location C and none at B on day 1. Form the vector \xvec_1 and determine the number of bicycles at the two locations the next day by finding \xvec_2 = A\xvec_1.
Suppose that one day there are 1050 bicycles at location B and 450 at location C. How many bicycles were there at each location the previous day?
Suppose that there are 500 bicycles at location B and 500 at location C on Monday. How many bicycles are there at the two locations on Tuesday? on Wednesday? on Thursday?

li.p: We solve the equation A\xvec = \twovec{1050}{450} to obtain \xvec = \twovec{1000}{500}.

If \xvec_1 = \twovec{500}{500} represents the distribution of bicycles on Monday, then \xvec_2=A\xvec_1 = \twovec{650}{350} represents the distribution of bicycles on Tuesday, \xvec_3=A\xvec_2=\twovec{695}{305} represents the distribution of bicycles on Wednesday, and \xvec_4=A\xvec_3=\twovec{708.5}{291.5} on Thursday.
\twovec{650}{350} represents the distribution of bicycles on Tuesday, \twovec{695}{305} represents the distribution of bicycles on Wednesday, and \twovec{708.5}{291.5} on Thursday.

statement.p:
This problem is a continuation of the previous problem.

Continuing in this way, explain why
\begin{aligned} \xvec_{3} = A\xvec_2 \amp {}={} c_1\vvec_1 +0.3^2c_2\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_{4} = A\xvec_3 \amp {}={} c_1\vvec_1 +0.3^3c_2\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_{5} = A\xvec_4 \amp {}={} c_1\vvec_1 +0.3^4c_2\vvec_2 \\ \end{aligned} .
Suppose that there are initially 500 bicycles at location B and 500 at location C. Write the vector \xvec_1 and find the scalars c_1 and c_2 such that \xvec_1=c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2.
Use the previous part of this problem to determine \xvec_2, \xvec_3 and \xvec_4.
After a very long time, how are all the bicycles distributed?
